title: Financial Future
description: Explore your vision for your financial life together and what you're building toward.

questions.text: When I imagine our financial future, I hope for...
choices: Complete financial freedom and flexibility
Security without worry about money
The ability to be generous with ourselves and others
Enough to live well without excess

therapeutic.rationale: Financial future visions reveal core values. Freedom-seekers want options; security-seekers want safety; generosity-seekers want impact; enough-seekers want simplicity. Shared vision aligns your efforts.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different visions may compete for resources. The freedom-seeker may clash with the security-seeker on how much to save vs. invest. Talk about what's behind each vision.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared vision means you're working toward the same financial life. This alignment is powerful.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What does your ideal financial future look like? What would be possible that isn't now?

questions.text: The financial milestone I most want us to reach is...
choices: Being debt-free
Owning a home (or our dream home)
Having substantial savings or investments
Being able to retire when we want

therapeutic.rationale: Priority milestones reveal what financial success means to you. Debt-free seekers want freedom from obligation; home-owners want stability; savers want security; retirees want time freedom. Partners may prioritize differently.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different priorities may need sequencing. Can you pay off debt while saving for a home? Talk about order and timeline—both goals may be achievable.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared milestone focus directs your joint effort. You're working toward the same target.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What financial milestone would change how you feel about your life? Why that one?

questions.text: When it comes to retirement, my thinking is...
choices: Plan early—I want to be prepared
It's far away—I'll figure it out later
Work as long as I enjoy it
Have options, even if I keep working

therapeutic.rationale: Retirement thinking reveals time orientation and security needs. Early-planners prioritize future security; later-thinkers prioritize present; work-enjoyers find purpose; option-havers want flexibility. Partners often have different timelines.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The early-planner may feel the later-thinker is irresponsible; the later-thinker may feel the early-planner is missing the present. Both perspectives have wisdom.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared retirement thinking makes long-term planning easier. You're naturally aligned on timeline.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you think about retirement? Does it feel real and worth planning, or distant and abstract?

questions.text: What I most want to build together financially is...
choices: A secure foundation for whatever comes
Resources to create the life we want
Something to pass on or give back
Freedom from financial stress

therapeutic.rationale: What you're building reveals purpose. Foundation-builders want security; life-creators want possibility; legacy-builders want impact; stress-freedom seekers want peace. Shared purpose strengthens partnership.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different building purposes may shape different strategies. The legacy-builder may want to invest differently than the stress-freedom seeker. Talk about what you're ultimately building toward.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared building purpose aligns your financial decisions. Every choice serves the same goal.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What are you trying to build financially? Why does that matter to you?

questions.text: The financial conversation I hope we keep having is...
choices: Are we on track toward our goals?
What do we want our life to look like?
How are we feeling about money right now?
What can we do differently or better?

therapeutic.rationale: Ongoing conversation focus reveals what sustains you. Track-checkers want progress; vision-explorers want alignment; feeling-checkers want emotional safety; improvers want growth. All are valuable—make room for each.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different ongoing conversation needs may leave one partner unsatisfied. The feeling-checker may need more emotional processing than the track-checker offers. Rotate between types.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared ongoing focus means your financial conversations will naturally center on what matters to both of you.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What financial conversation do you most look forward to having with your partner? What conversation do you avoid?
